content.body: I guess ES does not really have any "ASCII whitespace tests"? Anyway, people might find the fact that the web platform has multiple definitions of ASCII whitespace interesting. https://github.com/whatwg/infra/issues/670 plus, previously, https://github.com/whatwg/infra/pull/649
i would assume that anything that `/\s/` matches is considered whitespace. any other definition would be very surprising
content.formatted_body: i would assume that anything that /\s/ matches is considered whitespace. any other definition would be very surprising

content.body: well, the behavior of `\s` is based on General Category "Space_Separator" plus select additions and _not_ on property White_Space—as a result, U+0085 NEXT LINE (which has property White_Space) is not matched by it (regardless of flags), while U+FEFF ZERO WIDTH NO-BREAK SPACE (which does not have property White_Space) _is_ matched by it. See also https://github.com/tc39/ecma262/pull/3303 , which was unfortunately closed

content.body: i'm just saying that "\s" literally means "whitespace", so regardless of specs or standards or web reality, it'll be surprising if that doesn't hold

content.body: unicode nonsense doesn't change that either way :-)
ASCII whitespace is a useful thing to have in specs when attempting to parse data formats, etc. JSON has its own definition (which does not match JS's `\s` or `White_Space`).

content.body: sure, JSON is its own unique thing. we changed JS a number of years ago to include 2 more newline characters so it'd match JSON, as i recall
i think that regardless of what the current reality is, we should be striving to make there be a single definition of "whitespace", and for all things to match it
in particular, at least, i hope nobody would ever add an *additional* definition of "whitespace" :-)

content.body: I don't agree; I think it's useful for there to be separate definitions for whitespace and ASCII whitespace.
This is similar to how both lowercasing and ASCII lowercasing are useful operations, for example.
if the latter is a subset of the former, it might be fine, sure
i'm saying the ideal is one definition; more than one is fine, but we should be striving to minimize that. if we end up with two that's pretty decent.
the base64 proposal is the first place to my knowledge that introduces "ASCII whitespace" to JS https://tc39.es/proposal-arraybuffer-base64/spec/#sec-skipasciiwhitespace
it does not include vertical tab
this matches the infra definition, which is probably where I copied it from
